house_wash_vinyl: Saturate all surrounding landscaping, grass, and flower beds with fresh water to create a protective barrier against chemical runoff. [cite: 35]
Clear the siding of loose debris, spider webs, and bird nests using a low-pressure rinse or a soft-bristle extension brush. [cite: 36]
For standard cleaning: Prepare a downstream injection mix using Sodium Hypochlorite (SH) and Elemonator surfactant to kill algae and provide a fresh lemon scent. [cite: 37]
For heavy grime or "filthy" houses: Switch to a stronger solution of SH fortified with EBC (Enviro Bio Cleaner) degreaser to cut through heavy oils, soot, and industrial fallout. [cite: 38]
Apply the cleaning solution starting from the bottom of the house and working upward to prevent "clean streaks" caused by chemical rundown. [cite: 39]
Allow the specialized soap mixture to dwell for 10 to 15 minutes, ensuring the siding stays wet to effectively emulsify dirt and kill organic spores. [cite: 40]
Use downstream injector to apply the chemicals, keeping the pressure between 80 to 120 PSI to avoid forcing water behind the siding panels. [cite: 41]
Perform a thorough rinse from the top down, using high-volume, low-pressure water to flush all dirt and soap residues into the drainage system. [cite: 42]
Detail around windows, door frames, and soffits to ensure no soap film is left behind, which could cause spotting as it dries. [cite: 43]
Rinse the landscaping and grass a second time to dilute any chemical overspray and ensure the safety of your plants and pets. [cite: 44]
Conduct a final walk-around to inspect for "ghosting" or missed spots, re-treating stubborn areas if necessary before the surface dries. [cite: 45]
house_wash_masonry: Saturate the brick or stucco with fresh water for twice as long as standard siding to hydrate the porous substrate and prevent chemicals from being absorbed deep into the masonry. [cite: 46]
Clear surface obstructions like loose debris, webs, and nests using low-pressure air or water to avoid agitating fragile stucco finishes or aged mortar joints. [cite: 47]
Prepare a "hotter" chemical blend of Sodium Hypochlorite (SH) and Elemonator for standard cleaning to kill organic roots embedded deep within stone and stucco crevices. [cite: 48]
Switch to a heavy-duty mixture of SH and EBC for "filthy" masonry to emulsify deep-seated oils and soot bonded to the textured surface. [cite: 49]
Maximize surfactant cling by increasing the Elemonator ratio, ensuring the solution hangs onto the vertical texture of stucco and recessed mortar joints. [cite: 50]
Apply the cleaning solution from the bottom up to prevent "channeling" and permanent clean streaks. [cite: 51]
Implement extended dwell times of 15 to 20 minutes to allow chemicals to penetrate the pores and fully sanitize the material. [cite: 52]
Enforce ultra-low pressure at or below 100 PSI to prevent "blowing out" stucco or etching brick mortar. [cite: 53]
Execute a high-volume "Deep Flush" rinse using the full 4.0 GPM output to remove residual bleach salts trapped inside the pores. [cite: 54]
Perform a secondary "Plant Protection" rinse on all surrounding landscaping to dilute the stronger chemical concentrations. [cite: 55]
Monitor the surface during the drying process for mineral "ghosting" (efflorescence) that can be pulled to the surface. [cite: 56]
Monitor for "Ghosting": On brick, we check for faint white outlines once the wall begins to dry. [cite: 57]
If minerals are pulled to the surface, we immediately treat them with F9 Efflo while the wall is still damp. [cite: 58]
tennis_court: Clear the entire surface of loose debris, leaves, and organic matter using a high-powered blower. [cite: 59]
Identify if the court utilizes a Plexipave or DecoTurf system, as these cushioned acrylic surfaces require lower pressure to avoid de-lamination. [cite: 60]
Mix a specialized cleaning solution consisting of 1% to 2% Sodium Hypochlorite (SH) and a pH-neutral surfactant. [cite: 61]
Apply the solution evenly across the court using a low-pressure sprayer. [cite: 62]
Allow the solution to dwell for 15 minutes, re-wetting any areas that begin to dry to prevent chemical staining on the DecoTurf pigment. [cite: 63]
Agitate areas with heavy biological growth or bird droppings using a soft-bristled nylon brush. [cite: 64]
Execute a deep clean using a professional surface cleaner, ensuring the pressure at the nozzle is regulated below 1,500 PSI. [cite: 65]
Maintain a consistent walking speed with the surface cleaner, overlapping each pass by 2 inches. [cite: 66]
Detail all perimeter edges, net posts, and fence lines using a 40-degree wide-angle nozzle held 12 inches from the surface. [cite: 67]
Perform a high-volume, low-pressure rinse to flush all suspended solids and chemical residue toward the court’s primary drainage points. [cite: 68]
Squeegee excess standing water toward drains immediately to prevent mineral spotting or "birdbath" shadows on the acrylic. [cite: 69]
Conduct a final inspection for consistent coloration across the Plexipave or DecoTurf surface once it is partially dry. [cite: 70]
Apply a secondary moss inhibitor to high-shade areas if the environment is prone to rapid organic regrowth. [cite: 71]
Restrict all foot traffic for a minimum of 24 hours until the court is bone-dry and the grip-texture is fully stabilized. [cite: 72]
cement_driveway: Clear the concrete surface of all loose leaves, debris, and dirt using a high-powered blower. [cite: 73]
Spot treat oil spots and heavy tire marks with ZEP Purple or a professional-grade degreaser, allowing 15 minutes of dwell time. [cite: 74]
Scrub the treated spots with a stiff-bristle brush and rinse them thoroughly with fresh water before the solution dries. [cite: 75]
Apply a cleaning solution of SH, EBC degreaser, and surfactant using the soft-wash method via a downstream injector. [cite: 76]
Allow the chemical solution to dwell for 10 to 15 minutes to brighten the concrete and kill all organic spores. [cite: 77]
Perform a deep-clean of the entire driveway using a professional surface cleaner at a consistent pace. [cite: 78]
Cut in all edges, corners, and tight spaces using a 25-degree "Green" nozzle. [cite: 79]
Rinse all slurry, silt, and suspended contaminants toward the drainage points. [cite: 80]
Apply a "post-treat" solution of 2% to 3% SH using a pump sprayer and leave it to dry on the surface for maximum brightening. [cite: 81]
Spray Bleach Neutralizer on all nearby plants, grass, and landscaping. [cite: 82]
Conduct a final inspection of the work zone and use a high-powered blower to remove any remaining puddles. [cite: 83]
brick_driveway: Scrape away heavy moss, debris, and "muck" from the paver joints and dispose of it off-site. [cite: 84]
Pressure wash the entire area using a professional surface cleaner to strip away old sand, weeds, and surface contaminants. [cite: 85]
Detail-wash all walls, garage doors, and surrounding surfaces to remove any mud, sand, or slurry splatter. [cite: 86]
Perform a final high-volume rinse of the entire surface to ensure no silt or organic matter remains. [cite: 87]
Apply a specialized cleaning chemical (SH + Elemonator or F9 Efflo) to kill remaining organic spores and neutralize the pH. [cite: 88]
Agitate deep-seated oil or mineral stains with a stiff-bristle brush while the cleaning chemicals are active. [cite: 89]
Rinse the cleaning chemicals thoroughly with a wide-fan nozzle. [cite: 90]
Sweep high-quality, kiln-dried joint sand into the gaps until they are filled to within 1/8 inch of the paver chamfer. [cite: 91]
Use a leaf blower on low idle to remove all excess sand from the surface of the bricks. [cite: 92]
Inspect the job site for "sand-haze" and perform a final light misting rinse if necessary. [cite: 93]
Advise the client that the joint sand will require a 24-hour period to settle naturally before heavy rain or high-pressure hose use. [cite: 94]
dumpster_pad: Clear the pad and surrounding area of all loose trash, large debris, and heavy solids. [cite: 95]
Set the diesel burner to heat the water to a temperature between 180°F and 200°F to effectively liquefy solidified fats, oils, and greases (FOG). [cite: 96]
Apply a heavy-duty, alkaline-based degreaser (such as a Sodium Hydroxide or Potassium Hydroxide blend) at a high concentration. [cite: 97]
Use a specialized citrus-based solvent for targeted treatment of heavy oil stains or rubber tire marks. [cite: 98]
Allow the chemicals to dwell for 15 to 20 minutes, ensuring the pad remains wet. [cite: 99]
Scrub high-traffic areas and thick grease deposits with a stiff-bristle deck brush. [cite: 100]
Execute a deep-heat wash using a professional surface cleaner to strip away the liquefied grease. [cite: 101]
Maintain a slow, steady pace with the surface cleaner to allow the thermal energy to penetrate the porous concrete. [cite: 102]
Detail the vertical surfaces of the surrounding block walls and dumpster gates. [cite: 103]
Perform a high-volume hot water rinse to flush all emulsified oils toward the designated oil-water separator. [cite: 104]
Apply a professional-grade deodorizer and disinfectant to the pad and surrounding enclosure. [cite: 105]
Deploy an enzyme-based treatment post-wash to continue breaking down residual fats in the drainage system. [cite: 106]
Verify that all wastewater has been managed in accordance with local EPA and Clean Water Act regulations. [cite: 107]
rooftop_softwash: Saturate all surrounding landscaping and grass with fresh water to create a protective barrier. [cite: 108]
Mix a "hot" softwash solution using 12.5% Sodium Hypochlorite, a high-cling surfactant (soap), and a scent cover. [cite: 109]
Attach the X-Jet M5 nozzle to your spray wand and place the suction hose into the chemical bucket.
Apply the solution to the roof shingles starting from the bottom and working upward. [cite: 111]
Use the telescopic brush to gently agitate thick moss patches or heavy "Gloeocapsa Magma" while the surface is wet. [cite: 112]
Allow the cleaning solution to dwell for 20 to 30 minutes, ensuring the roof does not dry out.
Re-apply a light mist if necessary. [cite: 114]
Use the X-Jet's "rinse" setting or a low-pressure fan tip to thoroughly flush dead organic matter. [cite: 114]
Clear all gutters of the dislodged moss and debris to prevent clogs and ensure proper drainage. [cite: 115]
Rinse the siding, windows, and plants again to neutralize any overspray or runoff. [cite: 116]
Apply a professional Biocide (Quaternary Ammonium) as a final, non-rinse treatment to kill deep-seated spores.
Allow the Biocide to remain on the shingles; it will continue to clean the roof over the next several rain cycles. [cite: 118]
Perform a final walk-through to ensure all black streaks are gone and the landscaping remains healthy. [cite: 119]
garbage_bins: Position the bins at an incline on a wash pad area to ensure all wastewater is captured. [cite: 120]
Pre-spray the interior and exterior of the bins with a high-strength degreaser and a disinfectant solution containing at least 1% SH. [cite: 120]
Allow the sanitation solution to dwell for 5 to 10 minutes to break down organic waste and foul odors. [cite: 121]
Scrub the lids and any visible heavy residue with a long-handle stiff brush. [cite: 122]
Blast the interior surfaces with high-pressure hot water or a 25-degree nozzle to strip away grime and maggots. [cite: 123]
Rinse the exterior of the bin, including the wheels and handles. [cite: 124]
Apply a professional-grade deodorizer or an enzyme-based scent mask. [cite: 125]
Tip the bins upside down or use a high-powered blower to remove standing water. [cite: 126]
graffiti_removal: Pre-wet the surrounding non-affected surfaces with fresh water to prevent "ghosting" or chemical shadowing. [cite: 127]
Apply a professional-grade graffiti remover directly to the tags using a chemical-resistant brush. [cite: 128]
Allow the remover to dwell for 5 to 15 minutes without letting the product dry on the surface. [cite: 129]
Agitate the graffiti with a stiff-bristled brush to break the bond. [cite: 130]
Set the diesel burner to approximately 180°F to 200°F to melt the binders in the spray paint. [cite: 131]
Pressure wash the area using a 25-degree nozzle or a turbo nozzle, keeping the tip moving constantly. [cite: 132]
Apply a secondary "ghosting" remover or a light bleach solution if a faint outline remains. [cite: 133]
Rinse the entire wall from the top down to remove all residues and paint particles. [cite: 134]
Neutralize the pH of the surface if a high-alkaline remover was used. [cite: 135]
Customer's Option - Apply a sacrificial or permanent anti-graffiti coating. [cite: 136]
gum_removal: Clear the area of all loose trash and debris to reveal all gum spots. [cite: 137]
Set the diesel burner to a "steam" setting between 200°F and 212°F to effectively melt synthetic rubber. [cite: 138]
Pre-treat stubborn or "blackened" gum spots with a citrus-based solvent or specialized agent. [cite: 139]
Allow the chemical solvent to dwell for 3 to 5 minutes soft soften the bond. [cite: 140]
Utilize a specialized "gum nozzle" or a 15-degree fan tip at a 45-degree angle. [cite: 141]
Maintain a distance of 2 to 4 inches from the surface to avoid "cream coat" damage. [cite: 142]
Execute a full-surface cleaning with a professional surface cleaner once individual gum wads are detached. [cite: 143]
Perform a high-volume hot water rinse to flush away sticky residues. [cite: 144]
Apply a professional-grade degreaser or "brightener" to eliminate "ghosting" or shadows. [cite: 145]
Conduct a final inspection to ensure texture and color of concrete are uniform. [cite: 146]
Recover all wastewater and debris in accordance with local environmental regulations. [cite: 147]
efflorescence_algae_moss: Clear the area of all loose debris and vegetation using a high-powered blower. [cite: 148]
Saturate all nearby plants and grass with fresh water to prevent chemical burn. [cite: 149]
Apply a 3% Sodium Hypochlorite solution mixed with a surfactant to kill moss and algae spores. [cite: 150]
Allow the Sodium Hypochlorite solution to dwell for 10 to 15 minutes, keeping the surface wet. [cite: 151]
Pressure wash the surface with a professional surface cleaner to strip away dead organic sludge. [cite: 152]
Rinse the area thoroughly with high-volume water to remove all sludge and neutralize the SH. [cite: 153]
Inspect for white powdery stains (efflorescence) once the surface is damp. [cite: 154]
Apply a professional-grade efflorescence remover called F9 Efflo using a pump sprayer. [cite: 155]
Agitate the white deposits with a stiff-bristle nylon brush while the chemical is foaming. [cite: 156]
Allow the mineral remover to dwell for 2 to 5 minutes, never letting it dry. [cite: 157]
Perform a low-pressure rinse with a 40-degree nozzle to flush dissolved minerals. [cite: 158]
Neutralize the surface with a high-pH alkaline cleaner if required by the manufacturer. [cite: 159]
Conduct a final high-volume rinse of the entire project. [cite: 160]
Cordon off the driveway - Allow to dry completely for 48 hours before applying sealer. [cite: 161]
concrete_wash_reseal: Clear the concrete surface of all loose debris, dirt, and equipment. [cite: 162]
Pre-treat oil spots and heavy tire marks with a professional-grade degreaser (15-minute dwell). [cite: 163]
Perform a deep-clean of the entire surface using a professional surface cleaner. [cite: 164]
Rinse all slurry and suspended contaminants toward the drainage points. [cite: 165]
Apply Sodium Hypochlorite, degreaser, & surfactant solution to "brighten" the concrete. [cite: 166]
Allow the concrete to dry completely (typically 24 hours) for the sealant bond. [cite: 167]
Consult with the client to select either a 2–3 year Acrylic sealer or a 5–7 year Ure-Seal H2O. [cite: 168]
Apply the first coat of Ure-Seal H2O (or Acrylic) using a high-volume, low-pressure sprayer. [cite: 169]
Back-roll the wet sealer with a 3/8-inch nap roller to ensure even distribution. [cite: 170]
Apply a second coat of the chosen sealer after the first layer has become tack-free. [cite: 171]
Incorporate a slip-resistant additive into the final coat if the surface is sloped. [cite: 172]
Cordon off the driveway - Keep clear of foot traffic for 12 hours and vehicle traffic for 48 to 72 hours. [cite: 173]
brick_wash_reseal: Scrape away heavy moss, debris, and "muck" from the paver joints. [cite: 174]
Pressure wash the entire driveway using a professional surface cleaner to strip old sand and weeds. [cite: 175]
Detail-wash all walls, garage doors, and surrounding surfaces to remove mud or splatter. [cite: 176]
Perform a final high-volume rinse to ensure no silt remains on paver faces. [cite: 177]
Apply a specialized pre-seal cleaning chemical to neutralize pH and lift deep-seated stains. [cite: 178]
Rinse the cleaning chemicals thoroughly and allow pavers to dry overnight. [cite: 179]
Sweep high-quality, kiln-dried joint sand into the gaps until filled to within 1/8 inch of the chamfer. [cite: 180]
Use a leaf blower on low idle to remove all excess sand from the surface. [cite: 181]
Mix Ure-Seal H2O with the selected Ure-Seal Tint using a high-shear mixer. [cite: 182]
Apply the tinted Ure-Seal H2O layer evenly using a specialized sprayer or nap roller. [cite: 183]
Allow the tint layer to dry; if no tint, proceed to clear protective application. [cite: 184]
Apply a final flood coat of clear Ure-Seal H2O to lock in the sand joints. [cite: 185]
Cordon off the driveway for 24 hours for foot traffic and 48 to 72 hours for vehicles. [cite: 186]
concrete_dusting_shake: Clear the area of all loose debris, chalky dust, and dirt using a high-powered blower and stiff broom. [cite: 187]
Pressure wash the concrete with a professional surface cleaner to strip the weak surface and expose pores. [cite: 188]
Rinse the area thoroughly to ensure no silt remains to prevent bond failure. [cite: 189]
Apply a professional-grade liquid bonding adhesive while the concrete is slightly damp. [cite: 190]
Wait for the bonding agent to become "tacky" (usually 15–30 minutes) but not dry. [cite: 191]
Broadcast the Dry Shake Hardener powder evenly across the tacky surface. [cite: 192]
Allow the powder to sit for several minutes until it darkens from moisture absorption. [cite: 193]
Use a power float or hand trowel to work the powder into the surface, mechanically locking it. [cite: 194]
Apply a second light "dusting" of the powder to any thin or uneven areas. [cite: 195]
Trowel the surface again to a smooth, hard finish with no loose dry spots. [cite: 196]
Mist the surface very lightly with water if powder is not hydrating. [cite: 197]
Apply a curing compound or a Lithium Silicate densifier immediately after finishing. [cite: 198]
Cordon off the driveway- Allow 24 hours for foot traffic and 72 hours for heavy vehicles. [cite: 199]
resin_stone_stabilization: Clear the landscaping bed of all leaves, weeds, and organic debris. [cite: 200]
Level the existing rocks and ensure the area is bone-dry (moisture causes failure). [cite: 201]
Protect all surrounding edges and plant stems using masking tape or cardboard. [cite: 202]
Choose a high-quality binder (Easihold, Dominator Mulch Anchor, or two-part Polyurethane). [cite: 203]
Apply the resin using a pressurized pump sprayer or a "pour-on" method. [cite: 204]
Ensure the application rate is approximately 1 gallon per 50–100 square feet. [cite: 205]
Use a rake or trowel to agitate rocks if a "full-depth" bond is required. [cite: 206]
Apply a second "top-coat" mist after 1 hour to increase UV resistance. [cite: 207]
Allow the resin to cure for a minimum of 24 to 48 hours away from water or traffic. [cite: 208]
Check the weather forecast for 0% chance of rain for at least 24 hours. [cite: 209]
Conduct a "knock test" on the stones once dry to ensure they are firmly locked. [cite: 210]
Advise customer that a maintenance layer every 24 months helps prevent UV degradation. [cite: 211]
deck_fence_restoration: Clear the area of all furniture, planters, and decor to ensure unobstructed access to the wood surface. [cite: 212]
Saturate all surrounding vegetation and grass with fresh water to provide a protective shield against wood-cleaning chemicals. [cite: 213]
Apply Wood Wizzard Sodium Metasilicate using a low-pressure sprayer to break down weathered gray fibers, old failed stains, and organic growth. [cite: 214]
Allow the Sodium Metasilicate to dwell for 10 to 15 minutes, ensuring the wood remains wet to effectively emulsify the surface contaminants. [cite: 215]
Agitate heavily soiled areas or stubborn stains with a medium-bristle brush to lift deep-seated grime without damaging the wood grain. [cite: 216]
Pressure wash the wood using a wide 40-degree white nozzle, maintaining a consistent distance of 12 to 18 inches from the surface to prevent furring, etching, or splintering the fibers. [cite: 217]
Maintain a steady, sweeping motion along the full length of each board to avoid stop marks or gouging the wood with the 4.0 GPM stream. [cite: 218]
Rinse the wood thoroughly until the water runs clear and all chemical residue is removed from the surface and gaps. [cite: 219]
Apply Citric Acid to the damp wood as a secondary step to neutralize the pH and brighten the natural color of the lumber. [cite: 220]
Allow the Citric Acid to dwell for 5 to 10 minutes, observing as the wood shifts from a dark, dull tone to a vibrant, like-new appearance. [cite: 221]
Perform a final high-volume, low-pressure rinse to stabilize the wood and ensure all brightening agents are flushed away. [cite: 222]
Conduct a final rinse of all surrounding landscaping to ensure the area is clean and the soil pH is balanced. [cite: 223]
Allow the wood to dry for a minimum of 48 hours to reach the moisture levels required for any future coatings. [cite: 224]
Offer the client the optional Gold Standard finish: a professional restaining service once the wood is fully cured to preserve the newly restored look. [cite: 225]
gutter_cleaning: Clear all heavy debris, leaves, and organic matter from the gutter channels by hand or using specialized gutter scoops. [cite: 226]
Dispose of all collected debris into bags for off-site removal to ensure the lawn and landscaping remain pristine. [cite: 227]
Flush the gutter tracks with high-volume water to remove fine silt and ensure the internal drainage system is completely clear. [cite: 228]
Test every downspout by running water through the top to verify there are no hidden clogs in the elbows or underground extensions. [cite: 229]
Clear any identified downspout blockages using a plumbing snake or high-pressure water jetting until full flow is restored. [cite: 230]
Inspect the exterior face of the gutters for tiger striping—black streaks caused by electrostatic bonding of asphalt shingle runoff. [cite: 231]
Apply a professional Butyl Degreaser solution to the exterior of the gutters using a soft-wash applicator or specialized brush. [cite: 232]
Allow the Butyl solution to dwell for 3 to 5 minutes, ensuring the surface remains wet to chemically break the bond of the black streaks. [cite: 233]
Agitate the exterior surface gently with a soft-bristle brush or microfiber pad to lift the emulsified carbon and metallic runoff. [cite: 234]
Rinse the exterior gutters and the surrounding siding thoroughly with low-pressure water to reveal a bright, like-new finish. [cite: 235]
Perform a final perimeter walk-around to rinse any debris or cleaning solution from the ground, windows, and splash blocks. [cite: 236]
softwash_any_surface: Assess the material and surface type to determine the correct chemical compatibility and prevent potential damage. [cite: 237]
Saturate all nearby landscaping, grass, and sensitive vegetation with fresh water to create a protective barrier against cleaning solutions. [cite: 238]
Pre-treat the surface by clearing loose debris, cobwebs, or surface-level dirt using a high-volume, low-pressure rinse. [cite: 239]
Apply a customized soft wash solution, typically consisting of Sodium Hypochlorite (SH) for organic growth and Elemonator surfactant for maximum dwell time. [cite: 240]
Incorporate EBC (Enviro Bio Cleaner) into the mix if the surface exhibits heavy grease, oil, or industrial carbon buildup. [cite: 241]
Maintain an ultra-low pressure application (60–150 PSI) using a specialized J-Rod or soap nozzle to ensure the surface is sanitized without the risk of mechanical erosion. [cite: 242]
Allow the chemical solution to dwell for 10 to 15 minutes, monitoring the surface closely to ensure the product remains wet and active. [cite: 243]
Agitate stubborn stains or deep-seated grime with a soft-bristle nylon brush if the material texture allows for safe scrubbing. [cite: 244]
Execute a thorough, high-volume rinse using the full 4.0 GPM output of our system to flush away all emulsified dirt and chemical residues. [cite: 245]
Apply a specialized neutralizer (such as a Bleach Neutralizer or pH stabilizer) if the specific material requires a balanced finish to prevent future degradation. [cite: 246]
Perform a final Plant Protection rinse of the entire work area and all adjacent surfaces to ensure a safe and clean environment for pets and family. [cite: 247]
Conduct a final walk-through inspection with the client to ensure the Gold Standard clean has been achieved for their unique property. [cite: 248]
